While some officials at the DOJ have made it clear they have a strong interest and intent to file criminal charges against VW (and potentially its employees), there are several factors that make it extremely unlikely for the DOJ to files charges within this timeline. First of all, the burden of proof for criminal charges is much, much higher than the civil charges which have already been filed. The burden of proof for criminal charges is proof that VW "intentionally broke the law, beyond a reasonable doubt". Pursuing charges against individuals may be even more difficult, because in large and complex organizations like VW, it can be tough to prove that certain individuals had knowledge of ongoing fraud. A paper from the DOJ itself described the difficulty of pursuing individual charges, even though those charges can sometimes be the most potent force in taking on large organizations. Additionally, the VW case is much more complex than previous criminal cases which have been brought against automakers. Due to the highly technical nature of the scandal, the DOJ will need extra time to deliberate. A previous GJOpen forecast found that recent investigations for cases brought against automakers last 27 months on average. The VW scandal broke in September, which gives 6 months for a full investigation to complete before the deadline and criminal charges can be brought. Given the complex nature of this case, it is highly unlikely for this case to be so much shorter than other cases. Another area that makes this case more difficult than those brought against domestic carmakers (GM, for example) is that fact that VW is a German company. With ongoing investigations in Europe as well, there is a chance that the DOJ will allow the European authorities to have priority in bringing forward any potential charges. The final confounding factor is a legal loophole- automakers won exemption from criminal penalties in the 1970 Clean Air Act. In order to bring charges against VW, the DOJ will need to go through other methods, such as providing that VW employees intentionally lied to regulators. This further increases the complexity of an investigation. Given the short time frame, complexity of the case, and international element of the scandal, it is extremely unlikely for the US Justice Department to file criminal charges against VW or VW employees. The real point of interest here isn't the binary yes/no decision whether to prosecute -- that will emerge from the evidence, which currently seems tilted towards the notion of senior or at least near-senior executives intentionally approving emissions cheating. The main way VW could avoid charges will be to take a huge haircut in a nonprosecution agreement. That seems like a reasonably likely outcome; a complete walk-away by the DOJ is vanishingly unlikely. The interesting question is *timing*; whether the DOJ files charges (or ties up a settlement) before or after the end of March. They have near-complete freedom due to the 5-year statute of limitations in the Clean Air Act and VW's ongoing activity up until this year.  So: if you're DOJ, do you pull the trigger relatively quickly, or do you drag out negotiations with VW in hopes of getting to a negotiated settlement? There are lots of reasons to wait. You can still file charges later; you can watch to see what develops in Europe and elsewhere; you can add pressure to VW as it copes with the wide set of civil and criminal claims around the world. The main reason to go quickly in a criminal prosecution is to either avoid the destruction of evidence, or put an end to the criminal wrongdoing. But those concerns aren't present here -- the key evidence is probably already in DOJ hands, and the wrongdoing has indeed (likely) ceased. So the remaining reason to go fast or slow is politics, writ large or small. It seems unlikely that Democratic officials will officially sequence the prosecution to have effect on the election -- not clear what that effect would be, even if the officials were so inclined. Somewhat more likely that DOJ officials push the case to bolster their resume for a Clinton administration, but still, no need to have the homework done by end of March to achieve that end.
